summary.para: Contains information used in asynchronous (overlapped) input/output (I/O).

remarks.para: This structure should always be initialized to zero before it is used in a function call. If it is not, the function can fail and return ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER.
Use the function to cancel an asynchronous I/O operation.

A common mistake is to reuse an OVERLAPPED structure before the previous asynchronous operation has been completed. Use a separate structure for each request. Create an event object for each thread that processes data.

summary.para: Reserved for operating system use. This member, which specifies a system-dependent status, is valid when the function returns without setting the extended error information to ERROR_IO_PENDING.
Reserved for operating system use. This member, which specifies the length of the data transferred, is valid when the function returns TRUE.
File position at which to start the transfer. The file position is a byte offset from the start of the file. The calling process must set this member before it calls the or function.
High-order word of the file position at which to start the transfer.

Handle to an event that is set to the signaled state when the operation has been completed. The calling process must set this member either to zero or a valid event handle before it calls any overlapped functions. To create an event object, use the function. This function returns a handle that can be used to synchronize simultaneous I/O requests for a device.
Functions such as and set this handle to the nonsignaled state before they begin an I/O operation. When the operation has completed, the handle is set to the signaled state.

Functions such as and the wait functions reset auto-reset events to the nonsignaled state. Therefore, if an auto-reset event is used, the application can stop responding if it waits for the operation to complete and then calls IStreamAsync.OverlappedResult.
